  • project

The project command

Sets up a Corgi project.

Basic usage​

From your command line, cd into an empty project directory and run:

npx @corgi/cli project .

The dot . indicates the current working directory. You can also choose to specify a directory name instead.

You'll then be prompted to enter an optional template repo. For more information on templates, see the template option below.

Note

If using npx from a brand new directory as shown (as opposed to having the corgi command installed globally), you must ensure that NPM has been initialized in your directory (via npm init).

Arguments​

ArgumentsDescription
directoryRelative directory to create the project in. If you do not pass a directory argument, you will be prompted for one.

Examples​

npx @corgi/cli project .
npx @corgi/cli project my-cool-website

Options​

FlagShort flagDescription
--template-tOptional. URL of a Github repo's branch containing a Corgi template. Example: https://github.com/<user>/<repo>/tree/<branchname>. If you do not pass this flag, you will be prompted to enter an optional template.
--help-hDisplays a list of arguments and options.

Examples​

npx @corgi/cli project . --template https://github.com/<user>/<repo>/tree/<branchname>

Templates​

Pre-defined templates for Corgi projects can be pulled into your project automatically, by specifying the --template option within the project command. These templates must live within a branch of a github repo which you have access to. Templates are typically just sets of files which contain everything other than the existing Corgi framework — i.e. pre-defined pages, components, locales, and so on.

Custom config​

If custom template is specified, the project command will look for an optional JSON file located the root of the template repo, called corgi-project.config.json.

This config file can include overrides for the project, such as NPM dependencies, scripts, and a project name. The default Corgi config settings look like this:

{ 
  name: "corgi-project",
  dependencies: {},
  devDependencies: {},
  scripts: {},
}

You can overwrite any of these properties from within your template's corgi-project.config.json, like so:

corgi-project-config.json
{
  "name": "andrews-corgi-project",
  "dependencies": {},
  "devDependencies": {
    "eslint": "8.8.0",
    "eslint-config-next": "12.0.10",
    "eslint-config-prettier": "~8.3.0",
    "sass": "~1.49.7",
    "stylelint": "~14.5.1",
    "stylelint-config-standard-scss": "~3.0.0",
    "stylelint-order": "~5.0.0"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "serve-https": "node https-server.js"
  }
}
